title: Research
text:
My research focuses on mathematical models of mosquito population dynamics in response to environmental conditions such as temperature, rainfall, and photoperiod. I use deterministic and stochastic modeling approaches to simulate mosquito life stages, including diapause behavior.
I analyze the implications of seasonal climate change on Culex mosquito abundance and the potential for disease transmission, and apply sensitivity analysis to evaluate the robustness of model outcomes.

title: Joseph Baafi
text:
Joseph Baafi
PhD Candidate in Mathematical Biology | Infectious Disease & Ecological Modeling


Welcome
I am a PhD candidate in Mathematical Biology at Memorial University of Newfoundland.
My research focuses on climate-driven models of mosquito population dynamics, using temperature, rainfall, and photoperiod data to inform vector control and public health strategies.
I specialize in deterministic and stochastic modeling, ecological systems analysis, and the integration of climate data into mathematical frameworks.
I am proficient in R and LaTeX, and have practical experience using Python, Git and GitHub, MacOS and Linux for scientific computing.
I also have experience teaching undergraduate mathematics and R programming, and enjoy mentoring students in research, data analysis, and scientific communication.
